q: How can I check if I have a meniscus tear?
a: Symptoms of a meniscus tear include knee pain or tenderness, stiffness or swelling around the knee, difficulty bending or moving the knee, knee giving way when standing, and a crunching or clicking feeling when moving the knee.

q: What can I do to ease the symptoms of a meniscus tear?
a: To ease symptoms of a meniscus tear, you can rest your knee, apply ice packs for 20 minutes every 2 to 3 hours, wrap a bandage around your knee or wear a knee support, keep your leg raised, and take pain relief medication like paracetamol.

q: When should I see a GP for a meniscus tear?
a: You should see a GP if the knee pain is stopping you from doing normal activities or affecting your sleep, if the pain is getting worse or recurrent, if your symptoms have not improved after home treatment, or if your knee is stiff for more than 30 minutes after waking up.

q: What should I do if I have severe knee pain after a fall or injury?
a: If you have severe knee pain after a fall or injury, you should ask for an urgent GP appointment or get help from NHS 111. You can also call 111 or get help online.

q: When should I go to A&E for a meniscus tear?
a: You should go to A&E if your knee has moved out of place, changed shape, or is pointing at an odd angle, if you heard a crack during the injury, or if you experience tingling or no feeling in your knee, leg, or toes.

q: Can a meniscus tear heal on its own?
a: Yes, a meniscus tear can heal on its own without treatment, but it may take a while to heal.

q: What is physiotherapy recommended for a meniscus tear?
a: Physiotherapy may be recommended for a meniscus tear to help reduce pain and improve movement and strength in the knee.

q: When is arthroscopy surgery recommended for a meniscus tear?
a: Arthroscopy surgery may be recommended for a meniscus tear if the damage is severe and requires repair or removal of the damaged cartilage.

q: What can a pharmacist help with for a meniscus tear?
a: A pharmacist can help with painkillers and provide information on the types of knee supports available for a meniscus tear.

q: How does a meniscus tear usually happen?
a: A meniscus tear usually happens when you twist your knee while playing sports, but it can also occur from more minor injuries like twisting when standing up.

q: How can I check if I have a meniscus tear?
a: Symptoms of a meniscus tear include knee pain or tenderness, stiffness or swelling around the knee, difficulty bending or moving the knee, knee giving way, and crunching/clicking feeling when moving the knee.

q: What can I do to ease the symptoms of a meniscus tear?
a: To ease the symptoms, you can rest your knee, apply ice packs wrapped in a towel, wrap a bandage or wear a knee support, elevate your leg on a pillow, and take paracetamol for pain relief.

q: When should I see a GP for a meniscus tear?
a: You should see a GP if knee pain is affecting your daily activities or sleep, the pain is getting worse or recurring, your symptoms have not improved after home treatment, or if your knee is stiff for more than 30 minutes after waking up.

q: When should I seek urgent medical advice for a meniscus tear?
a: You should seek urgent medical advice if you have severe knee pain after a fall or injury, are unable to walk or put weight on your knee, the skin around your knee is swollen and feels hot, or if you have knee pain accompanied by a high temperature or feeling unwell.

q: What should I do if my knee is dislocated or I have no feeling in my knee?
a: If your knee has moved out of place, changed shape, or you have no feeling in your knee, leg, or toes, it is advised to go to A&E immediately or call 999 for an ambulance.

q: Can a meniscus tear heal without treatment?
a: Yes, a meniscus tear can heal on its own without treatment, but it may take some time.

q: What treatments are available for a meniscus tear?
a: Treatment options for a meniscus tear include physiotherapy to reduce pain and improve knee movement and strength, and in severe cases, arthroscopy surgery may be needed to repair or remove the damaged cartilage.

q: What are the symptoms of a meniscus tear?
a: Symptoms of a meniscus tear include knee pain or tenderness, stiffness or swelling around the knee, difficulty bending or straightening the knee, knee instability, and a crunching or clicking feeling when moving the knee.

q: How can I ease the symptoms of a meniscus tear?
a: To ease the symptoms of a meniscus tear, you can rest your knee, apply ice packs, wrap a bandage or wear a knee support, keep your leg elevated, and take pain relief medication such as paracetamol.

q: When should I see a GP for a meniscus tear?
a: You should see a GP if your knee pain is affecting your daily activities or sleep, if the pain is getting worse or recurring, if home treatment hasn't improved your symptoms, or if your knee is stiff for more than 30 minutes after waking up.

q: What should I do in case of urgent knee pain after a fall or injury?
a: In case of urgent knee pain after a fall or injury, you should ask for an urgent GP appointment or seek help from NHS 111 if you're unable to walk or put weight on your knee, if the skin around your knee is swollen and feels hot, or if you have a high temperature or feel hot and shivery.

q: What should I do if my knee has moved out of place or if I heard a crack during an injury?
a: If your knee has moved out of place, changed shape, or if you heard a crack during an injury, you should go to A&E immediately. If there is tingling or no feeling in your knee, leg, or toes, call 999 for an ambulance.

q: Can a meniscus tear heal on its own?
a: Yes, a meniscus tear can heal on its own without treatment, but it may take some time. However, in severe cases, arthroscopy surgery may be required to repair or remove the damaged cartilage.

q: What treatments are available for a meniscus tear?
a: Treatments for a meniscus tear may include physiotherapy to reduce pain and improve knee movement and strength. In severe cases, arthroscopy surgery may be necessary to repair or remove the damaged cartilage.

q: Can a pharmacist help with a meniscus tear?
a: Yes, you can ask a pharmacist about painkillers and the types of knee supports you can use for a meniscus tear.

q: How long does it take for a meniscus tear to heal?
a: The healing time for a meniscus tear can vary, but it can take a while. It is best to follow medical advice and recommendations for proper care and recovery.

q: What causes a meniscus tear?
a: A meniscus tear usually occurs due to twisting the knee while playing sports or from other minor injuries, such as twisting when standing up.
